text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored.

text: Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me. Family Member: Yeah guess the question I have is, what if for some reason the roads are really bad, the weather’s really bad? Are you flexible? Doctor: Oh, we would just reschedule. Oh, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes we have to be a little bit off cycle because, again, the weather for us is usually the big thing.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer. Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . text: Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-?

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay.

conv1028_2-snip9.displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Hum? Patient: Cancer’s like, uh, cancer is like a mucous. Doctor: Cancer is like a mucous? Patient: Huh. Doctor: Nah Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever. Doctor: Yeah. The cancer cells- Family Member: The cells just keep reproducing, reproducing, reproducing. Doctor: That’s it. It doesn’t know when to stop growing, which is the problem. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s, you know, affected your bones. It’s affected some of the lymph nodes. So is it going like crazy gangbusters? No. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: Many years ago. Doctor: And because it’s one kidney and you know whether the enzalutamide is doing anything, the protein, the diabetes, the losartan, the hypertension it all (noise) Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …and that’s just way too hard for me to keep up. I can only focus in on your prostate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m now going to send you to the expert. So if it’s not him then somebody else over will be fine. They’re all really good. Patient: Yeah we’ll get - What’s the, what’s the group that he’s in? Doctor: I think it’s really like B______ Nephrology. There’s only one big group there. Family Member: Okay. Patient: M___ Kidney Consultants. Oh, okay. Doctor: Yeah and they may be called that. Yep. Patient: And yeah, yeah that must be because that’s their office in R___ and T___...

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
